ExtendedSection.Title: Adding a full text search to your webpage

Text.name: Text0
Text.content:
You should use the way to build a website search describe here for testing. For a productive search, the configuration of the search via JSON instead of the the XML content might be more appropriate. The XML content should not be editable by users having no knowledge about searching with Solr. They are likely to misconfigure it. But, the content is great for testing.

OpenCms 10 provides the content type "Search Configuration" (jsp-search), that is available in the "System elements" content view. It comes with a default formatter that already can handle all combination of configuration options. Just create a page where your search should be located and place a "Search Configuration" on it.

Since OpenCms 11 the default formatter is not part of OpenCms anymore. You can download it here. Configure it for the type "jsp-search" to use it.

Open the content to see the available options:

Text.name: Text0
Text.content:
Via the configuration content all configuration options for <cms:search> are available. The different tabs represent the different search features. To get an overview, just click through the tabs, have a look at the options and read the tooltips. They are the best documentation.

You do not need to configure any option you do not use. Even with no configuration at all, you have a, thought simple, full text search.

The option you may need in nearly all cases is "Additional Solr Query Parameters" in the tab "Query options". Here you should specify your site root as parent folder, and possibly the types of content you want to search. See the tooltip for the editor field on how to do this.

As long as you have not written an own formatter for jsp-search, the default formatter is used. It can handle all the options, but may not yield the output you want. Hence, you should write your own formatter.
